channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Munich Killer Was Troubled, but Had No Terrorist Ties, Germany Says
item.description: The motivations of the gunman, an 18-year-old dual German-Iranian citizen, remained unclear. He had been treated for depression and complained of being bullied.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: A Sequel to the Paris Climate Accord Takes Shape in Vienna
item.media:description: Miguel Arias Cañete, the European commissioner for climate action and energy, met with Secretary of State John Kerry at the United Nations building in Vienna on Saturday. They are working on proposals to save the ozone layer.
item.description: Negotiators from around the world are working toward a ban on hydrofluorocarbons, coolants that replaced ozone-depleting chemicals but brought global warming problems of their own.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: By Russian Standards, Melania Trump Would Be a Plagiarism Amateur
item.media:description: Melania Trump at the Republican National Convention. Her speech led to talk of plagiarism, which is said to be commonplace in Russia.
item.description: The uproar over Melania Trump’s speech this week would barely tip the plagiarism scale in Russia, where an organization claims that many politicians have stolen others’ work.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Failed Turkish Coup Accelerated a Purge Years in the Making
item.media:description: A man hung a banner showing President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Taksim Square on Wednesday in Istanbul. Mr. Erdogan has imposed a sweeping purge of civil servants suspected of being disloyal.
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, whose officials had compiled lists of those with questionable loyalties, has labeled many civil servants as potential enemies of the state.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD, TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Vladivostok Lures Chinese Tourists (Many Think It’s Theirs)
item.media:description: A man fished off a pier in the central port of Vladivostok next to the headquarters of the Russian Pacific Fleet.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Nearly all Chinese who visit a city whose Russian name means “master of the East” think Vladivostok should be called Haishenwai, the name it had when China ruled.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: ISIS Claims Deadly Bombing at Demonstration in Kabul, Afghanistan
item.media:description: Hospitals treated the many Afghans wounded Saturday when suicide bombers struck a demonstration in Kabul, the capital.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Ethnic Hazaras were protesting peacefully in the capital when suicide attackers struck, killing at least 80 people.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and ZAHRA NADER

item.title: Indian Air Force Plane With 29 Aboard Disappears
item.media:description: An Indian Air Force AN-32 transport plane, in 2014, similar to the one that disappeared on Friday.
item.description: The plane, which is missing over the Indian Ocean, was carrying mostly service personnel, an official said.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: EgyptAir Flight 804 Broke Up in Midair After a Fire, Evidence Suggests
item.media:description: A United States Navy aircraft searched in May for debris from EgyptAir Flight 804, which crashed into the Mediterranean Sea, killing 66 people.
item.description: Investigators do not know, however, if the blaze that is thought to have caused the plane to come apart was an accident or caused by terrorism.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF and LIAM STACK

item.title: Delays Threaten to Unravel Iranian Plans to Buy 200 Jetliners
item.media:description: Iran Air passenger planes on the tarmac of the domestic Mehrabad airport in Tehran in 2013.
item.description: Fresh complications for an intended purchase that was seen as one of the most prominent commercial outcomes of a year-old nuclear accord.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Abroad in America: Donald Trump and the Limits of the Improv Campaign
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump speaking at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: Donald J. Trump had some good moments at his convention, but there were signs that his seat-of-the-pants style may be failing him.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Hungarian Leader, Viktor Orban, Says Donald Trump Is Better for Europe
item.description: Himself an proponent of building walls to keep migrants from entering his country, Hungary’s prime minister says the Republican nominee is just what Europe needs.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Basics: In Africa, Birds and Humans Form a Unique Honey Hunting Party
item.media:description: Orlando Yassene, a Yao honey-hunter, holding a male greater honeyguide that was temporarily captured for research in the Niassa National Reserve in Mozambique.
item.description: Tribesmen and honeyguides share an ancient pact and communicate in trills and grunts, scientists report. The shared goal: beehives full of honey and wax.
item.dc:creator: NATALIE ANGIER

item.title: Is There Any Hope for Peace in South Sudan?
item.media:description: Displaced people this month at the United Nations compound in Juba, South Sudan. Many in the city say they are frustrated with a government that has failed to ensure peace and stability for its people.
item.media:credit: Eric Kanalstein/U.N. Mission in South Sudan, via Associated Press
item.description: Residents of Juba, the capital, are caught in the crossfire of a power struggle between the rival factions of the country’s transitional government.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Indonesian Police Say DNA Confirms Most Wanted Terror Suspect Is Dead
item.description: The suspect, known as Santoso, was killed earlier in the week in a gun battle with Indonesian security forces.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Flooding in Northern China Kills Scores
item.media:description: Houses and fields partially submerged by floodwaters in Gaoyang Town, Shayang County, in China’s Hubei Province.
item.description: At least 72 people are dead and hundreds of thousands displaced in Hebei Province, where local governments took days to report casualties.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and KIKI ZHAO

item.title: Obama Denies U.S. Involvement in Coup Attempt in Turkey
item.description: Rumors that America was behind the failed military action threatened the safety of U.S. citizens in Turkey, Mr. Obama said, and could damage the nations’ ties.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Shooting in Munich: What We Know, and What We Don’t
item.media:description: The evacuation of the Olympia Shopping Mall in Munich on Friday.
item.description: Nine people were killed in a shooting rampage in Munich. The gunman’s body was found less than a mile from the scene of the attack, the police said.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Gunman in Munich Kills 9, Then Himself, the Police Say
item.description: The police said the attack outside a mall was probably the work of a single gunman. At least 21 people were wounded.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI, MELISSA EDDY and ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: I.M.F. Chief Faces Trial in France, Far From Duties in U.S.
item.media:description: Christine Lagarde, the International Monetary Fund chief, is expected to be required to spend more time away from her professional duties
item.description: The ruling, which will most likely require Christine Lagarde to spend more time away from her duties, threatens to overshadow her second term at the fund’s helm.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Canadian Lawyer Uncovers a Doping Scheme, and Russian Anger
item.media:description: Richard McLaren, a Canadian law professor, laid the groundwork for Russia’s potential Olympic ban with the release of his report, commissioned by the World Anti-Doping Agency.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Richard McLaren laid the groundwork for a potential ban of Russian athletes from the Rio Games with a report on how Russian doping had tainted numerous competitions.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.category: International Court of Arbitration for Sport

item.title: Downing Street and British Foreign Office Do Battle, and the Fur Flies
item.media:description: Larry sat outside 10 Downing Street during a cabinet meeting this week.
item.description: Britain’s new prime minister had been in office barely a week when a skirmish broke out between Larry the Cat and his counterpart on Whitehall, Palmerston.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Justice Dept. Rejects Account of How Malaysia’s Leader Acquired Millions
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia in Kuala Lumpur on Thursday. A spokesman said he had not changed his position that the hundreds of millions in his personal accounts came from an unidentified Saudi donor, not a government investment fund that he oversaw.
item.description: The Justice Department complaint alleges that the money was stolen from a Malaysian government investment fund that Prime Minister Najib Razak oversaw.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Search for Missing Malaysia Airlines Jet to Be Suspended
item.media:description: A member of the Royal Malaysian Air Force looking for the missing jet, Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, in 2014.
item.description: The hunt will be suspended if the plane isn’t found in the dwindling target zone, officials said, but it could be revived if new information emerged.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: What in the World: Recipe for a Chinese Ritual Dish: Eggs, Time and Plenty of Urine
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin / S-F / shutterstock.com
item.description: In Dongyang, “virgin boy eggs” are a traditional (and some say healthy) delicacy that depends on nature’s call to add just the right flavor.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: Why Libraries Are Everywhere in the Czech Republic
item.media:description: The library at the Strahov monastery in Prague.
item.media:credit: Pavel Horejsi for The New York Times
item.description: The country has a public library for every 1,971 people — 10 times the U.S. rate — and a population that still borrows and reads printed books.
item.dc:creator: HANA de GOEIJ

item.title: What in the World: That Green Square (or Circle) in Mexico City Might Save Your Life
item.description: Symbols painted on the sidewalks of the earthquake-prone city mark the places to gather when the tremors start.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The West’s Crisis of Leadership
item.media:description: The French police patrolling at Place de la République in Paris after the Nov. 13 attacks. Today, France and the United States are probably the West’s two main targets of Islamist terrorism.
item.description: Through 18 awful months, the French have proved remarkably resilient. More so than their officials.
item.dc:creator: SYLVIE KAUFFMANN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Who Was Behind the Coup Attempt in Turkey?
item.description: It seems likely that a Pennsylvania-based Muslim cleric initiated the putsch. The United States must help Turkey find justice.
item.dc:creator: MUSTAFA AKYOL
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Jihad and the French Exception
item.description: France is no more Islamophobic than its neighbors. It’s just more frontal in the way it handles Islam in the public sphere.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD KHOSROKHAVAR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
item.description: More than 8,000 men and boys were murdered in and around the city of Srebrenica in July 1995, the worst mass killing in Europe since World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
